newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan cotton rates steady on mill demand.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan cotton rates steady on mill demand.

text.p: Pakistani cotton rates held steady on Saturday mainly on demand from mill owners and dealers said prices would remain stable in the near term as arrivals of the 1997/98 (July-June) crop had proved slow.
"Prices held steady because mill owners are on the buying side," dealer Nasim Usmal said. "They are going for new and old crop stocks, while exporters are buyers at the lower levels."
He said prices would fall once the arrival of new crop picks up from Punjab province. "Right now Sindh (province) is a supplier to the mills in Punjab," he added.
In the kerb market, NIAB-78 was traded at 2,200 ($54.24) to 2,300 rupees per maund (37.32 k.g), dealers said.
Saturday's official spot rates issued by the KCA in rupees per maund including 12.5 percent sales tax:
